content.description:
This climb starts just right of a tree next to the base of the rock and is left of

Slabulous

. Climb up easy slab mixed with chickenheads to the anchor.

This is the second bolted line from the left. A techy start with small edges and a chickenhead guide you to a delicate slab crux. Finish with enjoyable face climbing. The anchor is shared with

Eye of the Tiger

.

This is a really enjoyable, well bolted, 2 pitch route. It can be linked with 20+ draws or with some backcleaning. The start can be identified by a black water streak just left of the fourth bolt.

Pitch 1 – 5.7.

Begin up gray colored slab to a few closely spaced bolts. Pull over a ledge, and climb on awesome chickenheads to the first anchor,

~100 feet & ~13 bolts.

Pitch 2 – 5.6.

Continue past the anchors up and left on nice slab. To finish, climb a broad arete to the second anchor. The rock is a little dirty but will clean up nicely with some traffic. Make two rappels back to the ground,

~65 feet & ~6 bolts.

This climb starts between two trees. A funky mantel-like move off the ground leads to the first bolt. Pull over a bulge, and climb easy terrain to a slab crux. Finish with more face climbing to the anchors.

The start of this shares a bit of real estate with

Slabby Lady

which starts between two trees. Follow the bolt line just left of

Slabby Lady

. The second bolt is in a hollow sounding bulge which may not be a good idea to whip on. About halfway up, do a mantel onto some slab (crux), and then finish with some face climbing.

This is an arcuate crack which starts near

One & Done

and ends at the

Slabulous

intermediate anchors.

Start as for

One & Done

, but move up and slightly right on featured rock until intersecting the obvious, left-curving crack/overlap flake. Work left along the crack. The crack turns up for about 10 feet prior to joining the roof and continuing left and slightly down to the intermediate double bolt anchors.
content.protection: Standard rack up up to BD #2. A #0.3 and #0.4 were also nice.
content.location:
On the right half of the main Slabulous wall, there are three left angling to vertical cracks. The first from left is a 5.6 disjointed crack. The second is unknown, perhaps 5.7-5.8. The third and most continuous is Round the Slab. Start as for

One & Done

, but move up and right until you intersect the crack.

This route crosses sport lines a few times and can almost be done with draws, minus the pendulum up top.

content.description: This climb is the second bolted line from the right and starts at the base of a dead tree that has fallen over. Climb up and right (4th class) to the first bolt. Continue up further to a ledge and the second bolt; then the real climbing begins. Climb up crystal slab to a bulge. Surmount the bulge (crux), and then cruise to the anchor.

If you're climbing with a 60m rope, be sure to tie knots in the end of your rope!

There wasn't much rope left with a 70m; you can probably climb up the 4th class ledges just right of the climb to make a 60m rope work.

This climb is the third bolted line from the right and starts at the base of a dead tree that has fallen over. Climb straight up the face to some enjoyable, crystal slab climbing. Bust over a bulge to a small bowl. Then climb the bowl directly (crux) to reach the anchor.

This is the furthest bolted line to the left. The crux comes between the first and second bolt. Good edges lead to significantly easier, enjoyable climbing. This shares anchors with

Slip Slabbin' Away

.

This is the furthest bolted line to the right and follows the eastern arete on the northern side of the Slabulous buttress. Climb up slabby crystals with no distinct crux to the top. The views to the north and east are spectacular.
